\begin{aligned} & \sum_{j=m}^nx_jy_j \\ = & \sum_{j=m}^n(s_j - s_{j-1})y_j \\ = & \sum_{j=m}^n (s_jy_j - s_{j-1}y_j) \\ = & \sum_{j=m}^n( s_jy_j - s_j y_{j+1} + s_j y_{j+1} - s_{j-1}y_j) \\ = & \sum_{j=m}^n ( s_jy_j - s_j y_{j+1}) + \sum_{j=m}^n (s_j y_{j+1} - s_{j-1}y_j) \\ \end{aligned}

If you expand the second term in the last equation

\sum_{j=m}^n (s_j y_{j+1} - s_{j-1}y_j) \\ = s_my_{m+1} - s_{m-1}y_m + s_{m+1}y_{m+2} - s_{m}y_{m+1} + s_{m+2}y_{m+3} - s_{m+1}y_{m+2} + \cdots + s_ny_{n+1} - s_{n-1}y_n

it turns out things cancel each out and only

s_ny_{n+1} - s_{m-1}y_m

remanins. Therefore

\sum_{j=m}^nx_jy_j = s_ny_{n+1} - s_{m-1}y_m + \sum_{j=m}^n s_j(y_j - y_{j+1})

Let (x_n) and (y_n) be sequences, let s_n = x_1 + x_2 + \cdots + x_n and set s_0 = 0. Use the observation that x_j = s_j - s_{j-1} to verify the formula

\sum_{j=m}^n x_jy_j = s_ny_{n+1} - s_{m-1}y_m + \sum_{j=m}^n s_j(y_j - y_{j+1}).

Abel's Test for convergence states that if the series \sum_{k=1}^\infin x_k converges, and if (y_k) is a sequence satisfying

y_1 \geq y_2 \geq y_3 \geq \cdots \geq 0,

then the series \sum_{k=1}^\infin x_k y_k converges.
Give an example of each or explain why the request is impossible referencing the proper theorem(s).

Proving the Alternating Series Test (Theorem 2.7.7) amounts to showing that the sequence of partial sums s_n = a_1 - a_2 + a_3 - \cdots \pm a_n converges. (The opening example in Section 2.1 includes a typical illustration of (s_n).) Different characterizations of completeness lead to different proofs.

Given a series \sum^\infin_{n=1}a_n with a_n \neq 0, the Ratio Test states that if (a_n) satisfies

\lim \left| \frac {a_{n+1}} {a_n} \right| = r < 1,

then the series converges absolutely.
